settings.title: Why does makeup expire?
settings.desc: Makeup products are bacteria magnets, Akram says, and the longer they’re laying around, the more bacteria they harbor. With that in mind, regularly assessing all your products and their expiration dates is highly recommended.

settings.title: What are telltale signs makeup has expired?
settings.desc: Telltale signs that a product is past its expiration date include changes in color, odor and texture. “Preservatives become less active when a product is reaching its expiration,” explains Akram. Dr. King says the same goes for non-makeup beauty tools such as washcloths, sponges, makeup brushes and applicators. Be sure to clean them regularly or swap them out for new ones.

settings.title: Do unopened beauty products expire?
settings.desc: Dr. King points out that these guidelines apply to makeup products that are opened and used. Unopened products have never been exposed to air, and likely aren’t contaminated. However, she says it's still important to keep an unopened product’s expiration date in mind. The active ingredients may be less potent,  and can degrade and irritate the skin over time. And even if the product is still effective and harmless, Dr. King says the longer it goes unused, it may be less enjoyable to use because it can become clumpy or dried out.

settings.quotes: ”If you notice the color has slightly changed or even the texture of the product, it’s time to toss it...”

settings.title: Lip products: 1 to 1.5 years
settings.desc: According to Akram, most lip product brands offer a one-and-a-half-year lifespan for lipsticks, and one year for lip glosses. And before you swipe on that old lipstick, this will make you think twice: “Applying expired lip products can cause a mild to severe lip rash, dry lips, and allergic reactions are also possible,” Akram says. That means lipsticks you purchased before the pandemic should be disposed of.

settings.title: Eyeshadow: 1 to 2 years
settings.desc: With powder eyeshadows, Akram says you’re good for about two years; cream shadows have a shorter lifespan of about a year. If the texture is off (e.g., it looks clumpy) or has an unusual smell, Akram says it’s best to toss it to avoid an eye infection or allergic reaction.

settings.title: Foundation: 1 to 1.5 years
settings.desc: Using expired foundation can result in acne, allergic reactions and other skin irritations, Akram says. This is why staying on top of expiration dates is vital. Expect a lifespan of a year for liquid and cream foundations, and a year and a half for powder foundations.

settings.title: Eyeliner: 3 months to 1 year
settings.desc: An eyeliner’s shelf life can range from three months to a year, depending on the formulation. “Creams and liquids tend to build up bacteria the quickest and have a shorter life span,” Akram says. “A pencil can last you up to a year, keeping in mind you’re shaving away most of the bacteria every time you sharpen it.”

settings.quotes: “...cleanse and spot treat with a mild salicylic or lactic treatment before applying a mineral-based sunscreen.”

settings.title: Strategically Apply Highlighter
settings.text_center: Gutierrez points out that while highlighter is a key product in creating a fresh, glowy face, it needs to be placed with care — especially if you’re experiencing breakouts. “Don’t put any kind of glow or highlight where you have a breakout or texture,” he explains. Doing so can draw unnecessary attention to the blemishes.

settings.title: SANITIZE BRUSHES DAILY
settings.text_center: Finally, Kizovski adds that using your fingers for makeup application on acne-prone skin should also be kept to a minimum and wash brushes often to avoid introducing bacteria onto the skin.

settings.quotes: ”Creams and liquids tend to build up bacteria the quickest and have a shorter life span.”

settings.title: Mascara: 3 months
settings.desc: Possible side effects of using expired mascara include lash shedding and eye infections. Akram and Dr. King agree,  it’s best to swap out your tube of mascara for a new one every three months.

settings.title: Blush and bronzer: 1 to 1.5 years
settings.desc: As with other face products, using expired blush or bronzer can lead to inflamed acne, skin irritations and rashes. To be safe, follow the suggested shelf life of one year to a year and a half, says Akram.

settings.title: Concealer: 6 to 8 months
settings.desc: “Concealers typically last about six to eight months,” Akram notes. “If you notice the color has slightly changed or even the texture of the product, it’s time to toss it. You can develop an eye infection, acne or other skin irritations."

settings.title: Highligher: 1 year
settings.desc: Whether you use a cream or powder highlighter, you’re good for about a year or maybe a little longer, Akram says.  Following this recommendation will help prevent bacteria build-up, skin redness, and rashes.

settings.title: Eyebrow products: 1 year
settings.desc: “Using an old brow product that most likely has built-up bacteria can lead to acne in your brows, brow shedding and clogged pores,” Akram says. ticking to a one-year shelf life for brow products is ideal.

settings.quotes: “Old products can be great breeding grounds for bacteria, yeast and molds.”

settings.title: Quick Guide: Makeup Expiration Dates
settings.text_center:
●  Lip products: 1 to 1.5 years

●  Eyeshadow: 1 to 2 years

●  Foundation: 1 to 1.5 years

●  Eyeliner: 3 months to 1 year

●  Mascara: 3 months

●  Blush and bronzer: 1 to 1.5 years

●  Concealer: 6 to 8 months

●  Highlight: 1 year

●  Eyebrow products: 1 year

settings.title: Quick Guide: Makeup Expiration Dates
settings.desc:
●  Lip products: 1 to 1.5 years

●  Eyeshadow: 1 to 2 years

●  Foundation: 1 to 1.5 years

●  Eyeliner: 3 months to 1 year

●  Mascara: 3 months

●  Blush and bronzer: 1 to 1.5 years

●  Concealer: 6 to 8 months

●  Highlight: 1 year

●  Eyebrow products: 1 year
